newsitem.title: INDIA: India shares close shade lower ahead of holiday.
newsitem.headline: India shares close shade lower ahead of holiday.

text.p: Indian blue chips ended lower in quiet trading on Monday as players waited nervously for a confidence vote in the government at the end of the week, traders said.
Both domestic and foreign funds remained on the sidelines, and are likely to stay there unless there is a fresh twist in New Delhi's politics ahead of Friday's vote.
"The uncertainty is increasing rather than decreasing," said Subra Subramanian, director at securities firm H.G. Asia. "This weekend has not helped much."
"Things are so much in the air -- the market will trade in a dead zone this week," the chief dealer at a U.K.-based brokerage said.
Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda's 15-party minority United Front alliance has to face a vote of confidence on Friday, after the Congress Party last week withdrew its crucial support to the government.

"I think we might see a period of low trading activity this week," said Himanshu Kaji, a member-broker of the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE). "The future course of the markets will depend on the crucial vote of confidence."
The government is also trying to put a contingency in place on Friday for its budget proposals.
Most political parties have said they would not allow the political impasse to derail the 1997/98 (April-March) February 28 budget which is still to be passed by Parliament.
"The Steering Committee of the United Front is going to meet on April 9 at 5 pm (1130 GMT)," United Front spokesman Jaipal Reddy told reporters in New Delhi on Monday.
"We will take a collective view on the budget and after that we will get in touch with the speaker (of the lower house of parliament) and other parties and evolve consensus view."
Bombay exchanges are closed on Tuesday for a local holiday.
